questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with conductive hearing loss. Imaging reveals a congenital anomaly involving the stapes footplate. Which embryological structure is primarily responsible for the development of the stapes footplate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Otic capsule

 

Explanation:

  • The stapes footplate develops from the otic capsule, a cartilaginous structure that surrounds the inner ear during development and later ossifies to form the bony labyrinth.
  • This capsule provides structural support and protection to the inner ear, which originates from the otic placode. (Option C)

 

Embryology of Ear

  • Development of Auricle:
    • Begins with proliferations from the first and second pharyngeal arches.
    • By the 6th week, six tubercles form around the first branchial cleft, which fuse to create the auricle.
    • Most of the auricle arises from the second pharyngeal arch, while the tragus and anterior meatus are derived from the first.
    • The lobule is the last part to develop.
    • By the 20th week of gestation, the pinna reaches its final adult shape.

  • External Auditory Meatus is developed by invagination of the first branchial cleft.

 

  • Middle Ear:
    • Includes the Eustachian tube, Tympanic cavity, Attic, Antrum, and Mastoid air cells, which develop from the endoderm of the tubotympanic recess
    • Ossicles:
      • Malleus and incus from the first arch (Option A)
      • Stapes from the second arch (Option B)
      • The Footplate of Stapes and annular ligament originates from the Otic capsule.

  • Membranous Inner Ear:
    • The ectoderm (neuroectoderm) in the hindbrain region thickens to form an Auditory placode, which invaginates into the auditory vesicle (otocyst) that develops into:
      • Endolymphatic duct and sac
      • Utricle and semicircular ducts
      • Saccule and cochlea

 

  • Tympanic Membrane:
    • Outer Layer: Ectoderm
    • Middle Layer: Mesoderm (fibrous)
    • Inner Layer: Endoderm (mucosal)
    • After a perforation, a healed tympanic membrane usually has only the ectoderm and endoderm, since the fibrous layer may not fully regenerate depending on the extent of damage.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is primarily responsible for the sensory innervation of the structure marked?

choices.text: Auricular branch of the vagus nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Explanation:

The marked structure in the image is Tragus, which is supplied by the Auriculotemporal Nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).

 

External Ear consists of two main parts:

  • Pinna (Auricle)
  • External Auditory Meatus

Aspects

Auricle (Pinna)

External Auditory Meatus

Composition

Elastic cartilage, except lobule (fibrofatty tissue)
  • Cartilaginous part (Outer 1/3) with hair and ceruminous glands
  • Bony part (Inner 2/3), with thin skin continuous with the tympanic membrane, lacks hair and glands.

Parts
  • Concha (Depression leading to the external meatus)
  • Helix (Prominent rim with anterior and posterior limbs)
  • Antihelix (Parallel ridge to the helix)
  • Tragus & Antitragus (Separated by inter-tragic notch)
  • Cymba Conchae (Above crus of helix)
  • Lobule (Soft, fleshy part below antitragus)

Nerve Supply

Lateral Surface

  • Lower third: Great auricular nerve (C2, C3)
  • Upper two-thirds: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
  • Concha: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) (Alderman’s Nerve)
 

Medial Surface

  • Lower third: Great auricular nerve
  • Upper two-thirds: Lesser occipital nerve (C2)
  • Roof & Anterior Wall: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
  • Floor & Posterior Wall: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X)

Clinical Relevance

McEwen’s triangle (Cymba Conchae)

  • It is a surgical landmark on the temporal bone to locate the mastoid antrum.

Furuncles (cartilaginous part) susceptible to infections

questions.text:
Match the following structures with their respective locations in the middle ear


 


	
		
			
			A. Tympanic Plexus
			
			
			1. Epitympanum
			
		
		
			
			B. Head of malleus
			
			
			2. Lateral wall
			
		
		
			
			C. Stapedius muscle
			
			
			3. Promontory of cochlea
			
		
		
			
			D. Tympanic membrane
			
			
			4. Mesotympanum
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 

Explanation:

Middle Ear (Tympanic cavity or Tympanum)

  • A narrow air-filled space located in the petrous part of the temporal bone, situated between the external ear and the internal ear.
  • Subdivisions:
    • Epitympanum (Attic): Located above the tympanic membrane, it contains the head of the malleus and the body and short process of the incus.
    • Mesotympanum: Opposite the tympanic membrane; contains the handle of the malleus, long process of the incus, and stapes. It is the narrowest part.
    • Hypotympanum: Located below the tympanic membrane.

 

  • Boundaries:

Boundaries of Middle ear cavity

Roof

(Tegmental Wall)

Formed by the Tegmen tympani, separating the middle ear from the middle cranial fossa.

Floor

(Jugular Wall)
  • A thin bony plate that separates the middle ear from the Internal Jugular Vein.
  • Tympanic canaliculus for the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Anterior Wall (Carotid Wall)
  • Separates the Middle ear from the Internal Carotid Artery
  • Upper part - Tensor Tympani canal.
  • Middle part - Auditory tube opening.
  • Inferior part - Perforated by Sympathetic nerves.

Posterior Wall (Mastoid Wall)
  • Aditus ad antrum: Opening to the mastoid antrum.
  • Fossa incudis: Lodges the short process of the incus.
  • Pyramid: Contains the stapedius muscle.
  • Posterior canaliculus for the chorda tympani nerve.

Lateral Wall (Membranous Wall)

The tympanic membrane, with contributions from the squamous temporal bone.

Medial Wall (Labyrinthine Wall)

Separates the Tympanic cavity from the internal ear

  • Promontory: Projection from the cochlea.
  • Oval Window: Opening for the stapes.
  • Round Window: Covered by the secondary tympanic membrane.
  • Prominence of Lateral Semicircular Canal
  • Tympanic Plexus formed by Glossopharyngeal nerve, is present on the promontory.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with dizziness and balance issues. The physician suspects a problem in the vestibular system. Which of the following structures is primarily responsible for detecting horizontal linear acceleration and head position relative to gravity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Utricle

 

Explanation:

  • The Utricle is a part of the vestibular system that detects horizontal linear acceleration and head position in relation to gravity, whereas the Saccule is responsible for vertical linear acceleration.
  • The semicircular canals detect rotational movements.
  • The Organ of Corti contains hair cells that convert sound vibrations into neural signals and are responsible for hearing.

 

Anatomy of the Inner Ear

The inner ear comprises two main components:

  • Membranous Labyrinth: A closed system of sacs and ducts filled with endolymph.
  • Bony Labyrinth: A rigid structure that encases the membranous labyrinth, with the space between them filled with perilymph.

 

Membranous Labyrinth Components:

  • Cochlear Duct (Scala Media):
    • It is located within the bony cochlea and contains the spiral organ of Corti, which is essential for hearing.
    • Has a spiral structure with 2¾ turns, positioned between the scala vestibuli and scala tympani.
    • Base: Formed by the osseous spiral lamina and the basilar membrane.
    • Roof: Formed by the vestibular membrane (Reissner’s membrane).

Sound Transmission:

Sound Waves → Travel through Perilymph (Scala vestibuli → Helicotrema → Scala tympani) → Generate fluid waves → Cause Basilar membrane to vibrate → Stimulate hair cells(Organ of Corti) → Convert sound vibrations into electrical signals → Sent to brain via Cochlear nerve.

 

  • Saccule:
    • A small sac within the vestibule, connected to both the cochlear duct and utricle.
    • Detects vertical movements via sensory receptors known as maculae.
  • Utricle:
    • A larger, oblong sac that connects to the semicircular ducts.
    • Primarily detects horizontal movements and head tilting through maculae.
  • Semicircular Ducts:
    • Located within the bony semicircular canals.
    • Contain Cristae ampullaris for detecting angular acceleration and maintaining kinetic balance.

Bony Labyrinth Components

  • Cochlea:
    • Converts sound waves into mechanical vibrations.
    • Structurally allows separation of sound frequencies, with higher frequencies detected at the basal coil and lower frequencies heard at the apical coil.
  • Vestibule: Central cavity situated between the cochlea and semicircular canals.
  • Semicircular Canals:
    • Three canals are oriented at right angles to each other, opening into the vestibule.
    • Vital for balance and spatial orientation, containing sensory structures (maculae in the vestibule and cristae in the semicircular canals) that detect head movements and positional changes.

questions.text:
Match the following labelled parts of the nasal septum:  




	
		
			
			1
			
			
			a. Septal Cartilage
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			b. Vomer
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			c. Palatine crest
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			d. Perpendicular Plate of Ethmoid
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4c

 

Explanation:

  • The nasal septum is a median osseocartilaginous partition that divides the two nasal cavities.
  • It typically deviates slightly to one side, most often to the right.

 

Structure of the Nasal Septum:

Bony Components

Cartilaginous Components
  • Perpendicular Plate of Ethmoid: Forms the posterosuperior part of the septum.
  • Vomer: Makes up the posteroinferior part.
  • Nasal spine of the frontal bone.
  • Crest formed by nasal bones.
  • Sphenoidal crest.
  • Nasal crest from the fusion of the palatine processes of the maxillae and horizontal plates of the palatine bones.
  • Septal Cartilage: Constitutes the major anterior part of the septum, fitting into the angle between the vomer and the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid.
  • Septal Processes of Alar Cartilages: The medial crura of the two major alar cartilages unite at the midline, forming the columella (or columellar septum).
  • Below the columella, a small portion of the septum comprises a double layer of skin without bony or cartilaginous support, known as the membranous septum.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the ENT clinic with persistent nasal congestion, facial pain, and reduced sense of smell. After minimal relief from medications, a nasal endoscopy is planned. Which of the following openings is not present in the structure labelled “X” in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Posterior ethmoidal air sinuses

 

Explanation:

The provided image depicts the lateral wall of the nose, with the structure labelled as the hiatus semilunaris, which contains three openings: The maxillary sinus, the frontal sinus, and the anterior ethmoidal air cells.

Lateral wall of the nose:

  • The conchae, or turbinates, are curved bony structures extending downward and medially.
  • They are classified into superior, middle, and inferior nasal conchae. Below these conchae lies over the recesses referred to as meatuses.
  • The atrium is a shallow depression located just in front of the middle meatus and above the nasal vestibule.
  • It is bordered superiorly by a slight mucous membrane ridge known as the agger nasi, which extends from the upper end of the middle concha.

Site

Location

Openings

Sphenoethmoidal recess

Triangular depression located above and behind the superior concha

Sphenoidal air sinus

Superior meatus

Lies below the superior concha (Smallest).

Posterior ethmoidal air sinuses (Option D)

Middle meatus
  • Lies underneath the middle concha.
  • Has the following parts:
    • Ethmoidal bulla /bulla ethmoidalis (round elevation produced by the underlying middle ethmoidal sinuses).
    • Hiatus semilunaris (semicircular sulcus below the bulla ethmoidalis).
    • Infundibulum (passage at the anterior end of middle meatus).

Bulla ethmoidalis: Middle ethmoidal air sinuses

 

Hiatus semilunaris:

  • Frontal air sinus (Option A)
  • Anterior ethmoidal air sinuses (Option C)
  • Maxillary air sinus (Option B)

Inferior meatus

Lies underneath the inferior nasal concha (Largest).

Nasolacrimal duct (in the anterior part of inferior meatus)

Hasner’s valve guards the opening of the nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child is experiencing excessive tearing in both eyes. The doctor recommends that the parents perform a massage along the nasolacrimal duct (NLD). How should the parents be instructed to carry out this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Downward, backward and lateral

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario describes a condition known as Epiphora in the bilateral eye, characterized by excessive tearing.
  • The canal involved in this condition is the Nasolacrimal Duct, which runs downward, backwards, and laterally.
  • Lacrimal glands produce tears and are located in the eye, draining into the nose through a membranous passage known as the nasolacrimal duct.
  • Massage in the direction of NLD encourages drainage and can assist in relieving blockages.

 

Nasolacrimal duct

Length

18 mm

Extent

It extends from the lacrimal sac and opens anteriorly into the inferior meatus of the nose.

Orientation

Runs downwards, backwards and laterally (Option A)

Valve

Hasner’s valve: An incomplete mucous fold at the lower end of the duct, preventing air from entering the duct and blowing into the eye when one blows their nose to clear nasal secretions.

Clinical aspect

Epiphora: Excessive secretion of the lacrimal fluid overflowing on the cheeks.

It may occur due to:

  • Hyperlacrimation: Excessive secretion of tears (intake of spicy food or emotional outbreak)
  • Obstruction in lacrimal passages (lacrimal punctum, lacrimal canaliculi, lacrimal sac and nasolacrimal duct)
  • Ectropion (eversion of lower eyelid).

Patency evaluation

Jones dye test 1 & 2 are procedures to assess the patency of the nasolacrimal duct and identify problems related to tear drainage.

questions.text: During retinoscopy, the ophthalmologist inquired of the intern about the development of the eyeball. Could you identify what will develop from the structure labeled "X" in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Light-sensitive neural layer

 

Explanation:

The marked structure in the above image represents the inner layer of the optic cup, which develops into the light-sensitive neural layer of the retina.

Development of Retina

  • The retina develops from the optic vesicle.

  • Retinal detachment: In retinal detachment there is separation of two layers of the retina (i.e., pigment and neural layers).

Optic nerve (Option A) is derived from optic stalk.

  • The center of the optic cup form the optic disc where the neural retina connects with the optic stalk, transforming it into the optic nerve.

Lens (Option B) develops from the lens vesicle.

  • The posterior cells of the vesicle form transparent primary lens fibers whereas the cells in the equatorial region produce secondary lens fibers.

Retinal pigment epithelium (Option D) is developed from the outer layer of the optic cup.

questions.text: All of the following structures pass through the area labeled "A" in the image except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lacrimal nerve

 

Explanation:

The image provided depicts the orbit. The ‘A’ marked structure is the inferior orbital fissure, which transmits the zygomatic nerve, infraorbital nerve, and pterygopalatine ganglion branches.

  • However, the lacrimal nerve is transmitted from the superior oblique fissure.

 

Anatomy of the Orbit:

  


Structures passing through superior and inferior orbital fissures

Superior orbital fissure

Inferior orbital fissure

Divided into three parts by the common tendinous ring of Zinn.

 
  • Within the common tendinous ring:
    • Superior and inferior divisions of the oculomotor (3rd cranial) nerve.
    • Nasociliary nerve
    • Abducent (6th cranial) nerve
    • Sympathetic root of the ciliary ganglion
 
  • Above and lateral to the common tendinous ring:
    • Trochlear (4th cranial) nerve
    • Frontal nerve
    • Lacrimal nerve
    • Lacrimal artery
    • Superior ophthalmic vein
    • Recurrent meningeal branch of the lacrimal artery.
  • Below and medial to the common tendinous ring: Inferior ophthalmic vein
  • Zygomatic nerve (Option A) 
  • Maxillary nerve
  • Branches of the pterygopalatine ganglion (Option C),
  • Infraorbital nerve and vessels (Option B)
  • Vein connecting inferior ophthalmic vein with pterygoid venous plexus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with difficulty lifting his right eye, describing it as "stuck" when looking upward, along with double vision. Examination reveals a significant limitation in the upward gaze of the right eye. What is the action of the structure labelled "A" in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

The structure marked in the given image is the Superior rectus muscle, which, in the primary position, performs elevation, adduction, and intorsion.

 

Extraocular muscles

 

Voluntary muscles

Involuntary muscles
  • Four recti muscles
    • Superior rectus
    • Inferior rectus
    • Medial rectus
    • Lateral rectus
 
  • Two oblique muscles
    • Superior oblique
    • Inferior oblique
 
  • Levator palpebrae superioris (1)
  • Superior tarsal or Muller's muscle
  • Inferior tarsal
  • Orbitalis.

Origin, insertion, and nerve supply of extraocular muscles:

 

Origin

Insertion

Nerve supply

Recti

Common annular tendon or tendinous ring of Zinn.

(all recti have the same origin)

Sclera little posterior to the limbus (corneoscleral junction)

 

The average distance from Limbus is:

  • Superior: 7.7 mm
  • Inferior: 6.5 mm
  • Medial: 5.5 mm
  • Lateral: 6.9 mm
  
  • Lateral rectus: Abducens nerve
  • Rest all other recti: Oculomotor nerve

Superior oblique

The undersurface of the lesser wing of the sphenoid

Into the sclera behind the equator in the posterior superior quadrant of the eyeball.

Trochlear nerve

Inferior oblique

The orbital surface of the maxilla

Into the sclera behind the equator in the posterior superior quadrant of the eyeball, a little below the superior oblique.

Oculomotor nerve

Levator palpebrae superioris

Orbital surface of the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone.

Superior lamella: Anterior surface of the superior tarsus and skin of the upper eyelid.

Inferior lamella: Upper margin of the superior tarsus and the superior conjunctival fornix.

 

Actions of muscles on the eyeball (Mnemonic):

SIN- Superior rectus/ Superior oblique assist i INtorsion

RAD- Rectus muscles help in ADduction

 

Superior rectus (SR)

(Option D)

Medial rectus (MR)

Inferior rectus (IR)

Lateral rectus (LR)

Superior oblique (SO)

Inferior oblique (IO)
  • Elevation
  • Adduction
  • Intorsion 
  • Adduction
  • Depression
  • Adduction
  • Extorsion
  • Abduction
  • Depression
  • Abduction
  • Intorsion
  • Elevation
  • Abduction
  • Extorsion

The 3-step (Parks-Bielschowsky) test is utilized to diagnose hypertropia resulting from superior oblique palsy.

  • The first step involves conducting the cover-uncover and alternate-cover tests to identify which eye is hypertrophic.
  • Next, the alternative-cover test is performed while the patient looks to the left and right, followed by tests during left and right head tilts.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is not typically injured during mandibular fracture repair?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Facial artery

Explanation:

Facial artery:

  • The facial artery supplies blood to the face, but it is typically not directly involved in mandibular fractures.
  • It is less likely to be injured in mandibular fracture repair, as it is located more superficially and does not directly supply the mandible.


Mandibular fractures often involve injury to the arteries that supply the mandible and its surrounding structures.

Inferior alveolar artery (Option A): This artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery, is commonly injured during mandibular fractures, especially in fractures of the body or angle of the mandible.
 

Lingual artery (Option B): The lingual artery, which supplies the tongue and floor of the mouth, can also be injured in fractures of the mandibular body or ramus. It is often at risk during fractures near the midline or in the region of the tongue.


Maxillary artery (Option D): This major artery supplies blood to the mandible through its branches, such as the inferior alveolar artery. It is closely related to the mandible, as it originates behind the neck and passes between the ramus and the sphenomandibular ligament.
